This engaging session began with a talk by Dr. Gregory Cartee (University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA) focusing on the role of exercise and diet on insulin signaling and glucose uptake by skeletal muscle. He provided evidence that AS160 activation is involved in the exercise-induced insulin-stimulated glucose uptake in skeletal muscle and that the response is influenced by the diet and exhibits fiber-type specificity. Dr. Sean Adams (Arkansas Children's Nutrition Center and The University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences, Little Rock, AR, USA) spoke on how exercise affects blood and muscle metabolomics patterns and gut-derived xenometabolites, Dr. Lauren Sparks (Translational Research Institute for Metabolism and Diabetes, Orlando, FL, USA) discussed molecular profiling of exercise responses in blood, muscle, and adipose tissues in obesity and diabetes, Dr. Kristin Stanford (The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, USA) provided evidence of a novel role for brown adipose tissue to improve cardiac function, and Dr. Sree Chintapalli (Arkansas Children's Nutrition Center and The University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences) spoke of the novel metabolic functions of myoglobin. The end of the first day featured the Poster Hall on the virtual platform, where participants engaged in live chats with the authors and other attendees. The second and final day of the virtual conference began with a session on Amino Acid Signaling, chaired by Dr. Tracy Anthony (Rutgers School of Environmental and Biological Sciences, New Brunswick, NJ, USA). Dr. Brendan Manning (Harvard T. H. Chan School of Public Health) gave a live talk on how mTORC1 connects growth signals to anabolic processes underlying cell growth. He presented exciting findings that the mTORC1-mediated activation of ATF4 contributes to enhanced protein, nucleotide, and glutathione synthesis and that the hepatic anabolic program downstream of mTORC1 affects liver and plasma macromolecules. Dr. John Blenis (Weill Cornell Medicine) discussed aging-associated metabolic signaling and cancer progression, Dr. Ron Wek (Indiana University School of Medicine, Indianapolis, IN, USA) spoke on nutrient signaling and the integrated stress response, Dr. Stefan Broer (Australian National University, Canberra, ACT, Australia) provided a unified model of amino acid homeostasis in mammalian cells, Dr. Adam Rose (Monash University, Melbourne, VIC, Australia) provided evidence that the restriction of essential amino acids dictates the systemic metabolic response to dietary protein dilution, and Dr. Dudley Lamming (University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA) spoke on the regulation of metabolic health by specific dietary macronutrients. Dr. Anthony concluded the session with a stimulating talk on amino acid control of protein homeostasis and her studies on the molecular sensing of amino acid insufficiency and the coordination of signal transduction to maintain proteostasis control. Participants had the opportunity to participate in a Career Development session with Dr. Teresa Davis (Editor-in-Chief, The Journal of Nutrition), Dr. Sue Bodine (Editor-in-Chief, The Journal of Applied Physiology), and Dr. Scot Kimball (Editorial Board Member of the American Journal of Physiology–Endocrinology and Metabolism and The Journal of Nutrition). This session provided insights into journal publishing, including manuscript preparation, journal selection, and the submission process. The final session of the conference was centered on the important topic of Nutrient Signaling Across the Life Cycle and was chaired by Dr. Blake Rasmussen (UTMB Health, Galveston, TX, USA). Lectures focusing on perinatal nutrient signaling were presented by Dr. Rebecca Simmons (University of Pennsylvania Medical School, Philadelphia, PA, USA), who discussed the effects of growth restriction and oxidative stress in the developmental programming of type 2 diabetes, and Dr. Laura Brown (University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, USA) who detailed her studies examining the effect of intrauterine growth restriction on nutrient signaling in a fetal sheep model. Dr. Elena Volpi (UTMB Sealy Center on Aging, Galveston, TX, USA) set the stage for lectures on nutrient signaling and aging with her overview of age-related changes in protein turnover, and the interaction of amino acids, insulin, and exercise in regulating protein synthesis in the elderly. Dr. Christopher Adams (University of Iowa Carver College of Medicine) discussed the role of ATF4 in muscle atrophy in aging, and Dr. Anna Thalackler-Mercer (Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, USA) presented recent work using muscle stem cells to investigate the interaction of aging and diet on muscle regeneration. Dr. Stuart Phillips (McMaster University, Hamilton, ON, Canada) rounded out the session in his presentation of anabolic signaling in muscle and the interaction of amino acids and resistance exercise in the regulation of protein synthesis. A second poster session was held and attendees were encouraged to participate in live chats with the authors. Dr. Teresa Davis closed the meeting by thanking all attendees, speakers, and sponsors for participating in this virtual meeting and announced the Poster Session awardees. Student Poster awards were presented to Alessandra Esposito (Telethon Institute of Genetics and Medicine, Naples, Italy) for a poster titled A Substrate-Specific mTORC1 Pathway Modulates TFEB Activity, Nicholas Lesner (University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Dallas, TX, USA) for a poster titled Alpha-Ketobutyrate Links Amino Acid Metabolism and Respiratory Activity in Mitochondrial Dysfunction, and Hala Haddad (Brown University, Providence, RI, USA) for a poster on The Role of Opsin 3 in Metabolism and Melanocortin Receptor-Mediated cAMP Signaling. Postdoctoral Fellow Poster awards were given to Dr. Daniel Levin (Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, USA) for a poster on NAD(H) Redox State Reprograms Transcription During Caloric Restriction, Dr. Paul Roberson (Penn State College of Medicine, Hershey, PA, USA) for a poster on Glucose-Induced mTORC1 Activation Occurs in a Sestrin-Dependent Manner, and Dr. Haejin Yoon (Harvard Medical School) for a poster on PHD3 Promotes Exercise Capacity and Fat Oxidation in Skeletal Muscle. In a post-conference evaluation, over 97% of those surveyed said they either strongly agreed or agreed that the research discussed was timely and relevant. One hundred percent of those surveyed agreed that FASEB was well prepared for the virtual meeting platform. Additionally, 90% said they would recommend this conference to others. Nutrition in pregnancy and early childhood affects later blood pressure and precursors of atherosclerosis, but its influence on arterial stiffness is unexplored. This study determines whether exposure to improved nutrition during early life influences Augmentation index (AI) and pulse wave velocity (PWV) in mid-adulthood. We included 1221 adults (37-54y) who participated in a cluster-randomized nutritional supplementation trial of a protein-energy beverage (Atole), conducted between 1969–1977 in Guatemala. The comparison group received Fresco, a low-calorie protein-free beverage. In 2015–17, we measured anthropometry (weight, height, and waist-to-height ratio); AI and PWV (using carotid—femoral tonometry); blood pressure; fasting plasma glucose and serum lipids; and sociodemographic characteristics. Based on patterns of exposure, we characterized participants as fully, partially or unexposed to the intervention from conception to their second birthday (the ‘first 1000 days’). We fit pooled and sex-specific models using intention-to-treat, difference-in-difference regression analysis to test whether exposure to the supplement in the first 1000 days was associated with AI and PWV in adulthood adjusting for basal and current sociodemographic variables and current life-style and cardio-metabolic risk factors. Prevalence of obesity in men and women was 39.6% and 19.6%, and prevalence of hypertension was 44.0% and 36.0%, respectively. Women had higher AI (34.4±9.6%) compared to men (23.0± 9.8%), but had similar PWV (7.60±1.13 m/s and 7.60±1.31, respectively). AI did not differ significantly across intervention groups. PWV was lower in individuals with full exposure to the supplement during the first 1000 days (-0.39m/s, 95% CI -0.87, 0.09; p = 0.1) compared to unexposed individuals. This difference was similar after adjusting for cardio-metabolic risk factors (-0.45m/s; 95%C-0.93, 0.01; p = 0.06). Exposure to improved nutrition during the first 1000 days was marginally associated with lower PWV, but not with AI.
